sections.content: Here's a trap many people fall into: they start tracking every penny and burn out within 2 weeks. Tracking should feel empowering, not exhausting. Let's find your sweet spot.

Instead of tracking daily, do a 10-minute check-in once a week. Sunday evening works great — the kids are in bed, you've got a cup of tea, and you review the week.

Here's all you need to check:
• How much did I save this week?
• Did I stick to my spending money?
• Any unexpected costs I need to plan for next week?
That's it. Three questions. Ten minutes. No spreadsheet required — your MumVest app does the tracking for you. You just need to log your savings when they happen.

sections.prompt: When is the best time in your week for a 10-minute money check-in? Pick a specific day and time that works for your family routine.

sections.content: Research shows that people who check their finances weekly (not daily, not monthly — weekly) have the best long-term financial outcomes. Daily is obsessive. Monthly is too late to course-correct. Weekly is the Goldilocks zone.
Track weekly, not daily. Three questions, ten minutes, one cup of tea. That's your entire financial management system.

You're building a sustainable habit, not a punishment. The families who get ahead aren't the ones who track obsessively — they're the ones who show up consistently. A weekly check-in you actually do beats a daily tracker you abandon!
